type.name: ChangeAuditStamps
type.doc: Data captured on a resource/association/sub-resource level giving insight into when that resource/association/sub-resource moved into various lifecycle stages, and who acted to move it into those lifecycle stages. The recommended best practice is to include this record in your record schema, and annotate its fields as @readOnly in your resource. See https://github.com/linkedin/rest.li/wiki/Validation-in-Rest.li#restli-validation-annotations

fields.name: created

type.name: AuditStamp
type.doc: Data captured on a resource/association/sub-resource level giving insight into when that resource/association/sub-resource moved into a particular lifecycle stage, and who acted to move it into that specific lifecycle stage.

fields.name: time

type.name: Time
type.doc: Number of milliseconds since midnight, January 1, 1970 UTC. It must be a positive number

fields.doc: When did the resource/association/sub-resource move into the specific lifecycle stage represented by this AuditEvent.

fields.name: actor
fields.doc: The entity (e.g. a member URN) which will be credited for moving the resource/association/sub-resource into the specific lifecycle stage. It is also the one used to authorize the change.

fields.name: impersonator
fields.doc: The entity (e.g. a service URN) which performs the change on behalf of the Actor and must be authorized to act as the Actor.

fields.name: message
fields.doc: Additional context around how DataHub was informed of the particular change. For example: was the change created by an automated process, or manually.
An AuditStamp corresponding to the creation of this resource/association/sub-resource. A value of 0 for time indicates missing data.

fields.name: lastModified
fields.doc: An AuditStamp corresponding to the last modification of this resource/association/sub-resource. If no modification has happened since creation, lastModified should be the same as created. A value of 0 for time indicates missing data.

fields.name: deleted
fields.doc: An AuditStamp corresponding to the deletion of this resource/association/sub-resource. Logically, deleted MUST have a later timestamp than creation. It may or may not have the same time as lastModified depending upon the resource/association/sub-resource semantics.
Captures information about who created/last modified/deleted this chart and when

items.name: Edge
items.doc:
A common structure to represent all edges to entities when used inside aspects as collections
This ensures that all edges have common structure around audit-stamps and will support PATCH, time-travel automatically.

fields.name: sourceUrn
fields.doc:
Urn of the source of this relationship edge.
If not specified, assumed to be the entity that this aspect belongs to.

fields.name: destinationUrn
fields.doc: Urn of the destination of this relationship edge.

fields.name: created
fields.doc: Audit stamp containing who created this relationship edge and when

fields.name: lastModified
fields.doc: Audit stamp containing who last modified this relationship edge and when

fields.name: properties
fields.doc: A generic properties bag that allows us to store specific information on this graph edge.

models.name: MLFeatureDataType
models.doc: MLFeature Data Type

symbolDocs.BINARY: Binary data is discrete data that can be in only one of two categories - either yes or no, 1 or 0, off or on, etc
symbolDocs.BYTE: Bytes data are binary-encoded values that can represent complex objects.
symbolDocs.CONTINUOUS: Continuous data are made of uncountable values, often the result of a measurement such as height, weight, age etc.
symbolDocs.COUNT:
Count data is discrete whole number data - no negative numbers here.
Count data often has many small values, such as zero and one.
symbolDocs.INTERVAL:
Interval data has equal spaces between the numbers and does not represent a temporal pattern.
Examples include percentages, temperatures, and income.
symbolDocs.MAP: Mapping Data Type ex: dict, map
symbolDocs.NOMINAL:
Nominal data is made of discrete values with no numerical relationship between the different categories - mean and median are meaningless.
Animal species is one example. For example, pig is not higher than bird and lower than fish.
symbolDocs.ORDINAL:
Ordinal data are discrete integers that can be ranked or sorted.
For example, the distance between first and second may not be the same as the distance between second and third.
symbolDocs.SEQUENCE: Sequence Data Type ex: list, tuple, range
symbolDocs.SET: Set Data Type ex: set, frozenset
symbolDocs.TIME:
Time data is a cyclical, repeating continuous form of data.
The relevant time features can be any period- daily, weekly, monthly, annual, etc.
symbolDocs.UNKNOWN: Unknown data are data that we don't know the type for.
symbolDocs.USELESS:
Useless data is unique, discrete data with no potential relationship with the outcome variable.
A useless feature has high cardinality. An example would be bank account numbers that were generated randomly.

models.name: Owner
models.doc: Ownership information

fields.name: owner
fields.doc:
Owner URN, e.g. urn:li:corpuser:ldap, urn:li:corpGroup:group_name, and urn:li:multiProduct:mp_name
(Caveat: only corpuser is currently supported in the frontend.)

fields.name: type

type.name: OwnershipType
type.doc: Asset owner types

symbolDocs.BUSINESS_OWNER: A person or group who is responsible for logical, or business related, aspects of the asset.
symbolDocs.CONSUMER:
A person, group, or service that consumes the data
Deprecated! Use TECHNICAL_OWNER or BUSINESS_OWNER instead.
symbolDocs.CUSTOM:
Set when ownership type is unknown or a when new one is specified as an ownership type entity for which we have no
enum value for. This is used for backwards compatibility
symbolDocs.DATAOWNER:
A person or group that is owning the data
Deprecated! Use TECHNICAL_OWNER instead.
symbolDocs.DATA_STEWARD: A steward, expert, or delegate responsible for the asset.
symbolDocs.DELEGATE:
A person or a group that overseas the operation, e.g. a DBA or SRE.
Deprecated! Use TECHNICAL_OWNER instead.
symbolDocs.DEVELOPER:
A person or group that is in charge of developing the code
Deprecated! Use TECHNICAL_OWNER instead.
symbolDocs.NONE: No specific type associated to the owner.
symbolDocs.PRODUCER:
A person, group, or service that produces/generates the data
Deprecated! Use TECHNICAL_OWNER instead.
symbolDocs.STAKEHOLDER:
A person or a group that has direct business interest
Deprecated! Use TECHNICAL_OWNER, BUSINESS_OWNER, or STEWARD instead.
symbolDocs.TECHNICAL_OWNER: person or group who is responsible for technical aspects of the asset.

fields.doc: The type of the ownership

fields.name: typeUrn
fields.doc:
The type of the ownership
Urn of type O

fields.name: source

type.name: OwnershipSource
type.doc: Source/provider of the ownership information

fields.name: type

symbolDocs.SERVICE: Other ownership-like service, e.g. Nuage, ACL service etc

fields.doc: The type of the source

fields.name: url
fields.doc: A reference URL for the source
Source information for the ownership

type.name: AzkabanJobType
type.doc: The various types of support azkaban jobs

symbolDocs.COMMAND:
The command job type is one of the basic built-in types. It runs multiple UNIX commands using java processbuilder.
Upon execution, Azkaban spawns off a process to run the command.
symbolDocs.GLUE: Glue type is for running AWS Glue job transforms.
symbolDocs.HADOOP_JAVA:
Runs a java program with ability to access Hadoop cluster.
https://azkaban.readthedocs.io/en/latest/jobTypes.html#java-job-type
symbolDocs.HADOOP_SHELL:
In large part, this is the same Command type. The difference is its ability to talk to a Hadoop cluster
securely, via Hadoop tokens.
symbolDocs.HIVE: Hive type is for running Hive jobs.
symbolDocs.PIG: Pig type is for running Pig jobs.
symbolDocs.SQL: SQL is for running Presto, mysql queries etc

fields.doc:
Datajob type
**NOTE**: AzkabanJobType is deprecated. Please use strings instead.

fields.name: flowUrn
fields.doc: DataFlow urn that this job is part of

fields.name: fineGrainedLineages

items.name: FineGrainedLineage
items.doc: A fine-grained lineage from upstream fields/datasets to downstream field(s)

fields.name: upstreamType

type.name: FineGrainedLineageUpstreamType
type.doc: The type of upstream entity in a fine-grained lineage

symbolDocs.DATASET: Indicates that this lineage is originating from upstream dataset(s)
symbolDocs.FIELD_SET: Indicates that this lineage is originating from upstream field(s)
symbolDocs.NONE: Indicates that there is no upstream lineage i.e. the downstream field is not a derived field

fields.doc: The type of upstream entity

fields.name: upstreams
fields.doc: Upstream entities in the lineage

fields.name: downstreamType

type.name: FineGrainedLineageDownstreamType
type.doc: The type of downstream field(s) in a fine-grained lineage

symbolDocs.FIELD: Indicates that the lineage is for a single, specific, downstream field
symbolDocs.FIELD_SET: Indicates that the lineage is for a set of downstream fields

fields.doc: The type of downstream field(s)

fields.name: downstreams
fields.doc: Downstream fields in the lineage

fields.name: transformOperation
fields.doc: The transform operation applied to the upstream entities to produce the downstream field(s)

fields.name: confidenceScore
fields.doc: The confidence in this lineage between 0 (low confidence) and 1 (high confidence)

fields.name: query
fields.doc:
The query that was used to generate this lineage. 
Present only if the lineage was generated from a detected query.

Fine-grained column-level lineages
Not currently supported in the UI
Use UpstreamLineage aspect for datasets to express Column Level Lineage for the UI

fields.doc: Unique id for the chart. This id should be globally unique for a dashboarding tool even when there are multiple deployments of it. As an example, chart URL could be used here for Looker such as 'looker.linkedin.com/looks/1234'

fields.name: username
fields.doc: The name of the AD/LDAP user.

fields.name: dashboardTool
fields.doc: The name of the dashboard tool such as looker, redash etc.

fields.name: dashboardId
fields.doc: Unique id for the dashboard. This id should be globally unique for a dashboarding tool even when there are multiple deployments of it. As an example, dashboard URL could be used here for Looker such as 'looker.linkedin.com/dashboards/1234'

fields.name: orchestrator
fields.doc: Workflow manager like azkaban, airflow which orchestrates the flow

fields.name: flowId
fields.doc: Unique Identifier of the data flow

fields.name: cluster
fields.doc: Cluster where the flow is executed

fields.name: flow
fields.doc: Standardized data processing flow urn representing the flow for the job

fields.name: jobId
fields.doc: Unique Identifier of the data job

ref.name: SchemaMetadata
ref.doc: SchemaMetadata to describe metadata related to store schema

fields.name: schemaName
fields.doc: Schema name e.g. PageViewEvent, identity.Profile, ams.account_management_tracking

fields.name: platform
fields.doc: Standardized platform urn where schema is defined. The data platform Urn (urn:li:platform:{platform_name})

fields.name: version
fields.doc: Every change to SchemaMetadata in the resource results in a new version. Version is server assigned. This version is differ from platform native schema version.

fields.name: dataset
fields.doc: Dataset this schema metadata is associated with.

fields.name: cluster
fields.doc: The cluster this schema metadata resides from

fields.name: hash
fields.doc: the SHA1 hash of the schema content

fields.name: platformSchema

type.name: EspressoSchema
type.doc: Schema text of an espresso table schema.

fields.name: documentSchema
fields.doc: The native espresso document schema.

fields.name: tableSchema
fields.doc: The espresso table schema definition.

type.name: OracleDDL
type.doc: Schema holder for oracle data definition language that describes an oracle table.

fields.name: tableSchema
fields.doc: The native schema in the dataset's platform. This is a human readable (json blob) table schema.

type.name: MySqlDDL
type.doc: Schema holder for MySql data definition language that describes an MySql table.

fields.name: tableSchema
fields.doc: The native schema in the dataset's platform. This is a human readable (json blob) table schema.

type.name: PrestoDDL
type.doc: Schema holder for presto data definition language that describes a presto view.

fields.name: rawSchema
fields.doc: The raw schema in the dataset's platform. This includes the DDL and the columns extracted from DDL.

type.name: KafkaSchema
type.doc: Schema holder for kafka schema.

fields.name: documentSchema
fields.doc: The native kafka document schema. This is a human readable avro document schema.

fields.name: documentSchemaType
fields.doc: The native kafka document schema type. This can be AVRO/PROTOBUF/JSON.

fields.name: keySchema
fields.doc: The native kafka key schema as retrieved from Schema Registry

fields.name: keySchemaType
fields.doc: The native kafka key schema type. This can be AVRO/PROTOBUF/JSON.

type.name: BinaryJsonSchema
type.doc: Schema text of binary JSON schema.

fields.name: schema
fields.doc: The native schema text for binary JSON file format.

type.name: OrcSchema
type.doc: Schema text of an ORC schema.

fields.name: schema
fields.doc: The native schema for ORC file format.

type.name: Schemaless
type.doc: The dataset has no specific schema associated with it

type.name: KeyValueSchema
type.doc: Schema text of a key-value store schema.

fields.name: keySchema
fields.doc: The raw schema for the key in the key-value store.

fields.name: valueSchema
fields.doc: The raw schema for the value in the key-value store.

type.name: OtherSchema
type.doc: Schema holder for undefined schema types.

fields.name: rawSchema
fields.doc: The native schema in the dataset's platform.
The native schema in the dataset's platform.

fields.name: fields

items.name: SchemaField
items.doc: SchemaField to describe metadata related to dataset schema.

fields.name: fieldPath
fields.doc: Flattened name of the field. Field is computed from jsonPath field.

fields.name: jsonPath
fields.doc: Flattened name of a field in JSON Path notation.

fields.name: nullable
fields.doc: Indicates if this field is optional or nullable

fields.name: description
fields.doc: Description

fields.name: label
fields.doc:
Label of the field. Provides a more human-readable name for the field than field path. Some sources will
provide this metadata but not all sources have the concept of a label. If just one string is associated with
a field in a source, that is most likely a description.

Note that this field is deprecated and is not surfaced in the UI.

fields.name: created
fields.doc: An AuditStamp corresponding to the creation of this schema field.

fields.name: lastModified
fields.doc: An AuditStamp corresponding to the last modification of this schema field.

type.doc: Schema field data types

fields.name: type

type.doc: String field type.

type.name: BytesType

type.name: NumberType
type.doc: Number data type: long, integer, short, etc..

type.name: DateType
type.doc: Date field type.

type.name: TimeType
type.doc: Time field type. This should also be used for datetimes.

type.name: EnumType
type.doc: Enum field type.

type.name: NullType
type.doc: Null field type.

type.name: MapType
type.doc: Map field type.

fields.name: keyType
fields.doc: Key type in a map

fields.name: valueType
fields.doc: Type of the value in a map

type.name: ArrayType

fields.doc: List of types this array holds.

type.name: UnionType

fields.doc: List of types in union type.

type.name: RecordType
type.doc: Record field type.

fields.doc: Data platform specific types
Platform independent field type of the field.

fields.name: nativeDataType
fields.doc: The native type of the field in the dataset's platform as declared by platform schema.

fields.name: recursive
fields.doc: There are use cases when a field in type B references type A. A field in A references field of type B. In such cases, we will mark the first field as recursive.

fields.name: globalTags
fields.doc: Tags associated with the field

fields.name: glossaryTerms
fields.doc: Glossary terms associated with the field

fields.name: isPartOfKey
fields.doc:
For schema fields that are part of complex keys, set this field to true
We do this to easily distinguish between value and key fields

fields.name: isPartitioningKey
fields.doc:
For Datasets which are partitioned, this determines the partitioning key.
Note that multiple columns can be part of a partitioning key, but currently we do not support
rendering the ordered partitioning key.

fields.name: jsonProps
fields.doc:
For schema fields that have other properties that are not modeled explicitly,
use this field to serialize those properties into a JSON string
Client provided a list of fields from document schema.

fields.name: primaryKeys
fields.doc: Client provided list of fields that define primary keys to access record. Field order defines hierarchical espresso keys. Empty lists indicates absence of primary key access patter. Value is a SchemaField@fieldPath.

fields.name: foreignKeysSpecs

values.name: ForeignKeySpec
values.doc: Description of a foreign key in a schema.

fields.name: foreignKey

type.name: DatasetFieldForeignKey
type.doc: For non-urn based foregin keys.

fields.name: parentDataset
fields.doc: dataset that stores the resource.

fields.name: currentFieldPaths
fields.doc: List of fields in hosting(current) SchemaMetadata that conform a foreign key. List can contain a single entry or multiple entries if several entries in hosting schema conform a foreign key in a single parent dataset.

fields.name: parentField
fields.doc: SchemaField@fieldPath that uniquely identify field in parent dataset that this field references.

type.name: UrnForeignKey
type.doc: If SchemaMetadata fields make any external references and references are of type com.linkedin.common.Urn or any children, this models can be used to mark it.

fields.name: currentFieldPath
fields.doc: Field in hosting(current) SchemaMetadata.
Foreign key definition in metadata schema.
Map captures all the references schema makes to external datasets. Map key is ForeignKeySpecName typeref.

fields.name: foreignKeys

items.name: ForeignKeyConstraint
items.doc: Description of a foreign key constraint in a schema.

fields.name: name
fields.doc: Name of the constraint, likely provided from the source

fields.name: foreignFields
fields.doc: Fields the constraint maps to on the foreign dataset

fields.name: sourceFields
fields.doc: Fields the constraint maps to on the source dataset

fields.name: foreignDataset
fields.doc: Reference to the foreign dataset for ease of lookup
List of foreign key constraints for the schema

ref.name: EditableSchemaMetadata
ref.doc:
EditableSchemaMetadata stores editable changes made to schema metadata. This separates changes made from
ingestion pipelines and edits in the UI to avoid accidental overwrites of user-provided data by ingestion pipelines.

fields.doc: Data Type of the MLFeature

fields.name: sources

fields.name: name
fields.doc: Name of the MLModel

fields.name: origin
fields.doc: Fabric type where model belongs to or where it was generated

ref.name: CaveatsAndRecommendations
ref.doc: This section should list additional concerns that were not covered in the previous sections. For example, did the results suggest any further testing? Were there any relevant groups that were not represented in the evaluation dataset? Are there additional recommendations for model use?

fields.name: caveats

type.name: CaveatDetails
type.doc: This section should list additional concerns that were not covered in the previous sections. For example, did the results suggest any further testing? Were there any relevant groups that were not represented in the evaluation dataset? Are there additional recommendations for model use?

fields.name: needsFurtherTesting
fields.doc: Did the results suggest any further testing?

fields.name: caveatDescription
fields.doc:
Caveat Description
For ex: Given gender classes are binary (male/not male), which we include as male/female. Further work needed to evaluate across a spectrum of genders.

fields.name: groupsNotRepresented
fields.doc: Relevant groups that were not represented in the evaluation dataset?

This section should list additional concerns that were not covered in the previous sections. For example, did the results suggest any further testing? Were there any relevant groups that were not represented in the evaluation dataset?

fields.name: recommendations
fields.doc: Recommendations on where this MLModel should be used.

fields.name: idealDatasetCharacteristics
fields.doc: Ideal characteristics of an evaluation dataset for this MLModel

ref.name: EthicalConsiderations
ref.doc: This section is intended to demonstrate the ethical considerations that went into MLModel development, surfacing ethical challenges and solutions to stakeholders.

fields.name: data
fields.doc: Does the MLModel use any sensitive data (e.g., protected classes)?

fields.name: humanLife
fields.doc: Is the MLModel intended to inform decisions about matters central to human life or flourishing - e.g., health or safety? Or could it be used in such a way?

fields.name: mitigations
fields.doc: What risk mitigation strategies were used during MLModel development?

fields.name: risksAndHarms
fields.doc: What risks may be present in MLModel usage? Try to identify the potential recipients, likelihood, and magnitude of harms. If these cannot be determined, note that they were considered but remain unknown.

fields.name: useCases
fields.doc: Are there any known MLModel use cases that are especially fraught? This may connect directly to the intended use section

ref.name: EvaluationData
ref.doc: All referenced datasets would ideally point to any set of documents that provide visibility into the source and composition of the dataset.

fields.name: evaluationData
dataset
fields.doc: What dataset were used in the MLModel?

fields.name: motivation
fields.doc: Why was this dataset chosen?

fields.name: preProcessing
fields.doc: How was the data preprocessed (e.g., tokenization of sentences, cropping of images, any filtering such as dropping images without faces)?
Details on the dataset(s) used for the quantitative analyses in the MLModel

ref.name: IntendedUse
ref.doc: Intended Use for the ML Model

fields.name: primaryUses
fields.doc: Primary Use cases for the MLModel.

fields.name: primaryUsers
fields.doc: Primary Intended Users - For example, was the MLModel developed for entertainment purposes, for hobbyists, or enterprise solutions?

fields.name: outOfScopeUses
fields.doc: Highlight technology that the MLModel might easily be confused with, or related contexts that users could try to apply the MLModel to.

ref.name: Metrics
ref.doc: Metrics to be featured for the MLModel.

fields.name: performanceMeasures
fields.doc: Measures of MLModel performance

fields.name: decisionThreshold
fields.doc: Decision Thresholds used (if any)?

ref.name: MLModelFactorPrompts
ref.doc: Prompts which affect the performance of the MLModel

fields.name: relevantFactors

items.name: MLModelFactors
items.doc: Factors affecting the performance of the MLModel.

fields.name: groups
fields.doc:
Groups refers to distinct categories with similar characteristics that are present in the evaluation data instances.
For human-centric machine learning MLModels, groups are people who share one or multiple characteristics.

fields.name: instrumentation
fields.doc:
The performance of a MLModel can vary depending on what instruments were used to capture the input to the MLModel.
For example, a face detection model may perform differently depending on the camera's hardware and software,
including lens, image stabilization, high dynamic range techniques, and background blurring for portrait mode.

fields.name: environment
fields.doc: A further factor affecting MLModel performance is the environment in which it is deployed.
What are foreseeable salient factors for which MLModel performance may vary, and how were these determined?

fields.name: evaluationFactors
fields.doc: Which factors are being reported, and why were these chosen?

ref.name: MLModelProperties
ref.doc: Properties associated with a ML Model

include.name: MLModelLineageInfo
include.doc: A set of re-usable fields used to capture lineage information for ML Models and ML Model Groups

fields.name: trainingJobs
fields.doc: List of jobs or process instances (if any) used to train the model or group. Visible in Lineage. Note that ML Models can also be specified as the output of a specific Data Process Instances (runs) via the DataProcessInstanceOutputs aspect.

fields.name: downstreamJobs
fields.doc: List of jobs or process instances (if any) that use the model or group.

fields.name: name
fields.doc: Display name of the MLModel

fields.name: description
fields.doc: Documentation of the MLModel

fields.name: date
fields.doc: Date when the MLModel was developed

fields.name: created

fields.name: lastModified
fields.doc: Date when the MLModel was last modified

fields.name: version
fields.doc: Version of the MLModel

fields.name: type
fields.doc: Type of Algorithm or MLModel such as whether it is a Naive Bayes classifier, Convolutional Neural Network, etc

Hyper Parameters of the MLModel

ref.name: QuantitativeAnalyses
ref.doc: Quantitative analyses should be disaggregated, that is, broken down by the chosen factors. Quantitative analyses should provide the results of evaluating the MLModel according to the chosen metrics, providing confidence interval values when possible.

fields.name: unitaryResults

type.name: ResultsType
type.doc: A union of all supported metadata aspects for ResultsType

fields.doc: Link to a dashboard with results showing how the MLModel performed with respect to each factor

fields.name: intersectionalResults
fields.doc: Link to a dashboard with results showing how the MLModel performed with respect to the intersection of evaluated factors?

ref.name: TrainingData
ref.doc: Ideally, the MLModel card would contain as much information about the training data as the evaluation data. However, there might be cases where it is not feasible to provide this level of detailed information about the training data. For example, the data may be proprietary, or require a non-disclosure agreement. In these cases, we advocate for basic details about the distributions over groups in the data, as well as any other details that could inform stakeholders on the kinds of biases the model may have encoded.

fields.name: trainingData
fields.doc: Details on the dataset(s) used for training the MLModel
